<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_shrink_read_buffer:
```c
static void
connection_shrink_read_buffer (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  void *new_buf;

  if ((NULL == c->read_buffer) || (0 == c->read_buffer_size))
  {
    mhd_assert (0 == c->read_buffer_size);
    mhd_assert (0 == c->read_buffer_offset);
    return;
  }

  mhd_assert (c->read_buffer_offset <= c->read_buffer_size);
  if (0 == c->read_buffer_offset)
  {
    MHD_pool_deallocate (c->pool, c->read_buffer, c->read_buffer_size);
    c->read_buffer = NULL;
    c->read_buffer_size = 0;
  }
  else
  {
    mhd_assert (MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (c->pool, c->read_buffer, \
                                               c->read_buffer_size));
    new_buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (c->pool, c->read_buffer, c->read_buffer_size,
                                   c->read_buffer_offset);
    mhd_assert (c->read_buffer == new_buf);
    c->read_buffer = new_buf;
    c->read_buffer_size = c->read_buffer_offset;
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment modifies the function parameter pointer 'connection' itself. The function immediately creates a const pointer alias: 'struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection;' — the pointer variable c is const and not reassigned. All subsequent writes are to members of the object pointed to (e.g. c->read_buffer, c->read_buffer_size, c->read_buffer_offset), which is permitted by Rule 17.8 (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified). There are no assignments to the parameter identifier 'connection'. The calls to MHD_pool_deallocate/MHD_pool_reallocate and the mhd_assert checks operate on members of *c and do not change the pointer parameter. Therefore no fragments need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
